questions.text: What is the maximum time frame for completing an initial assessment after receiving a referral?
questions.explanation: Initial assessments must be completed within 72 hours of receiving a referral to ensure timely service delivery. See manual pages 12, 15 for detailed information.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT considered a mandatory reporter under FCS guidelines?
questions.explanation: Neighbors and community members are encouraged but not mandated to report concerns. Mandatory reporters include professionals who work directly with children. See manual pages 8, 9, 23 for detailed information.

questions.text: A family's income is 185% of the Federal Poverty Level. Are they eligible for FCS services?

options.C: Yes, if they meet other criteria

questions.explanation: Families up to 200% FPL may be eligible if they meet other qualifying criteria such as risk factors or special circumstances. See manual pages 18, 19, 31 for detailed information.

questions.text: How often must a comprehensive case review be conducted for active cases?
questions.explanation: Comprehensive case reviews must be conducted every 90 days to ensure services remain appropriate and goals are being met. See manual pages 42, 43 for detailed information.

questions.text: What documentation is required when a parent refuses services?

options.B: Written refusal form signed by parent

questions.explanation: A written refusal form must be signed by the parent and maintained in the case file to document informed refusal of services. See manual pages 27, 28, 55 for detailed information.

questions.text: During a home visit, you observe potential safety hazards. What is your first action?
questions.explanation: First document observations and assess if there is immediate risk to the child. Action depends on severity and immediacy of danger. See manual pages 34, 35, 36 for detailed information.

questions.text: What is the minimum frequency for face-to-face contact with children in care?
questions.explanation: Face-to-face contact with children in care must occur at minimum monthly to monitor well-being and placement stability. See manual pages 47, 48 for detailed information.

questions.text: A 17-year-old youth is aging out of care. When should transition planning begin?
questions.explanation: Transition planning must begin at age 16 to ensure adequate preparation for independence and connection to adult services. See manual pages 61, 62, 63 for detailed information.

questions.text: Which consent is required for routine medical care of a child in foster care?
questions.explanation: Foster caregivers have authority to consent for routine medical care. Major medical procedures may require additional approvals. See manual pages 52, 53 for detailed information.

questions.text: How long must case records be retained after case closure?
questions.explanation: Case records must be retained for 7 years after case closure to meet state and federal requirements. See manual pages 68, 69 for detailed information.

questions.text: What constitutes 'imminent risk' requiring immediate intervention?

options.B: Threat of serious harm within 24-48 hours

questions.explanation: Imminent risk means threat of serious harm likely to occur within 24-48 hours without intervention. See manual pages 37, 38, 39 for detailed information.

questions.text: A parent requests their case file. What information can be withheld?
questions.explanation: Third-party information and details that could compromise safety investigations may be redacted. Most other information must be provided. See manual pages 71, 72, 73 for detailed information.

questions.text: When must a supervisor review and approve a safety plan?
questions.explanation: Safety plans require supervisor review and approval within 24 hours to ensure appropriate protective measures. See manual pages 40, 41 for detailed information.

questions.text: What is the maximum caseload for ongoing FCS workers?
questions.explanation: Maximum caseload for ongoing workers is 20 cases to ensure quality service delivery and compliance with standards. See manual pages 76, 77 for detailed information.

questions.text: Which factor automatically qualifies a family for intensive services?
questions.explanation: Previous substantiated abuse with a new referral automatically qualifies for intensive services due to elevated risk. See manual pages 20, 21, 22 for detailed information.

questions.text: How soon must initial contact be attempted after case assignment?
questions.explanation: Initial contact must be attempted within 24 hours of case assignment to begin engagement and assessment process. See manual pages 13, 14 for detailed information.

questions.text: What triggers mandatory reporting to law enforcement?

options.B: Suspected criminal conduct or severe physical abuse

questions.explanation: Law enforcement must be notified for suspected criminal conduct or severe physical abuse requiring investigation. See manual pages 24, 25, 26 for detailed information.

questions.text: When can services be terminated without family agreement?

options.C: When safety concerns are resolved and court orders completed

questions.explanation: Services can be terminated when safety concerns are resolved and any court-ordered requirements are completed, even without family agreement. See manual pages 65, 66, 67 for detailed information.

questions.text: What assessment tool is required for all new investigations?
questions.explanation: Structured Decision Making (SDM) tools must be used for all investigations to ensure consistent assessment. See manual pages 32, 33 for detailed information.

questions.text: How many business days to complete a comprehensive family assessment?
questions.explanation: Comprehensive family assessments must be completed within 30 business days to determine service needs and develop plans. See manual pages 16, 17 for detailed information.

questions.text: Which situation requires a formal staffing with supervisory team?

options.B: Cases with disagreement on safety decisions

questions.explanation: Formal staffing with supervisory team is required when there's disagreement on safety decisions or complex case decisions. See manual pages 78, 79 for detailed information.

questions.text: What percentage of visits must occur in the child's residence?
questions.explanation: At least 50% of visits must occur in the child's residence to properly assess living conditions and family dynamics. See manual pages 49, 50 for detailed information.

questions.text: When is parental consent NOT required for services?

options.B: Court-ordered services or immediate safety concerns

questions.explanation: Parental consent is not required for court-ordered services or when immediate safety concerns necessitate intervention. See manual pages 29, 30 for detailed information.

questions.text: What must be included in every case plan?
questions.explanation: Case plans must include specific, measurable goals with clear timeframes and responsibilities. See manual pages 44, 45, 46 for detailed information.

questions.text: How long do families have to appeal a service decision?
questions.explanation: Families have 30 days from notification to appeal service decisions through the formal appeals process. See manual pages 74, 75 for detailed information.

questions.text: What training is required within first year of employment?

options.B: Core training plus 40 hours continuing education

questions.explanation: New workers must complete core training plus 40 hours of continuing education within first year. See manual pages 80, 81, 82 for detailed information.

questions.text: Which children require monthly photographs for documentation?
questions.explanation: Monthly photographs are required for children under 5 or non-verbal children to document physical condition. See manual pages 54, 55 for detailed information.

questions.text: What determines eligibility for kinship care placement?

options.B: Background check and home study approval

questions.explanation: Kinship placements require background checks and home study approval regardless of relationship. See manual pages 57, 58, 59 for detailed information.

questions.text: When must critical incidents be reported to state office?
questions.explanation: Critical incidents must be reported to state office within 2 hours of discovery for immediate review. See manual pages 83, 84 for detailed information.

questions.text: What action requires court approval within 72 hours?
questions.explanation: Emergency removal requires court hearing within 72 hours to review and approve continued placement. See manual pages 85, 86, 87 for detailed information.

questions.text: Which families are eligible for voluntary prevention services?

options.B: Any family requesting help before crisis

questions.explanation: Any family can request voluntary prevention services before crisis to strengthen family functioning. See manual pages 88, 89 for detailed information.

questions.text: What is required for interstate placement of children?
questions.explanation: Interstate Compact on Placement of Children (ICPC) approval is required for all interstate placements. See manual pages 60, 90, 91 for detailed information.

questions.text: How often must concurrent planning be reviewed?
questions.explanation: Concurrent planning must be reviewed at every court hearing to ensure timely permanency. See manual pages 92, 93 for detailed information.

questions.text: What threshold must be met for substantiated finding?
questions.explanation: Preponderance of evidence (more likely than not) is the standard for substantiated findings. See manual pages 94, 95 for detailed information.

questions.text: When can information be shared without release?
questions.explanation: Information can be shared between agencies without release when necessary for child protection. See manual pages 96, 97 for detailed information.

questions.text: What requires immediate notification to placing agency?

options.B: Serious injury, allegation, or placement disruption

questions.explanation: Serious injuries, abuse allegations, or placement disruptions require immediate notification. See manual pages 98, 99 for detailed information.

questions.text: How long to complete adoption home studies?
questions.explanation: Adoption home studies must be completed within 120 days of application for timely processing. See manual pages 100, 101 for detailed information.

questions.text: What age can youth sign their own service agreements?
questions.explanation: Youth can sign their own service agreements at age 18 when they reach legal majority. See manual pages 102, 103 for detailed information.

questions.text: Which medication requires court approval for children in care?
questions.explanation: Psychotropic medications require court approval to ensure appropriate oversight and monitoring. See manual pages 104, 105 for detailed information.

questions.text: What is minimum education requirement for FCS workers?
questions.explanation: Minimum requirement is Bachelor's degree in social work or related human services field. See manual pages 106, 107 for detailed information.
